title: Contextualizing Search Queries In-Context Learning for Conversational Rewriting with LLMs
author: Raymond Wilson (National Energy University), Chase Carter (National Energy University), Cole Graham (National Energy University), ...
relevance_why: The proposed method of conversational query rewriting could be adapted for use in audio-language alignment or improving interactive systems in audio applications.
background: Transforming context-dependent user queries into context-independent queries suitable for search engines, particularly in conversational settings.
contribution: This paper introduces Prompt-Guided In-Context Learning to solve conversational query rewriting, achieving significant performance improvements across benchmark datasets.
technical_comparison: Previous methods relied heavily on large labeled datasets for training, which are scarce in low-resource settings. This work improves by utilizing few-shot in-context learning techniques without requiring extensive fine-tuning.
key_innovation: Unique in its approach to leverage pre-trained Large Language Models (LLMs) for query rewriting through designed prompts without the need for explicit training.
real_world_impact: Could enhance conversational AI interactions, making systems like voice assistants more effective in understanding user intents in lower-resource environments.
limitations: Does not adequately address potential biases in conversational contexts or the adaptability of the model to different languages and cultures.

new_terms.in-context learning: **In-context learning** refers to the capability of a model to learn and adapt to new tasks by using context provided in prompts without requiring explicit parameter tuning.
new_terms.prompt-guided learning: **Prompt-guided learning** involves structuring input prompts to guide model behavior and understanding in achieving desired outputs.
